Award.AwardTitle: Order from Disorder: Tuning Long-Range Magnetic Ordering by Chemical Doping in Strongly Correlated Intermetallics
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
An experimental investigation of the electronic and magnetic ground states in novel intermetallic systems is proposed. Emphasis will focus on the synthesis and characterization of small band-gap semiconductors, including, a series of compounds related to FeGa3 and the alkaline earth and rare earth hexaborides. The properties of these strongly correlated electron materials depend sensitively on parameters such as sample stoichiometry, carrier density, temperature, chemical/physical pressure, and magnetic field. The long-range magnetic order induced by chemical doping in the non-magnetic semiconductor FeGa3 will be studied. A ferromagnetic quantum critical point (FM-QCP) was recently discovered which points toward a novel structural feature driving the criticality - the density of mixed valent Fe-Fe dimer "singlets". Second, this project will investigate the possibility of raising the ferromagnetic ordering temperature in doped Kondo insulators. FeSi is the classic example, and shows similar properties to that of FeGa3. Measurements of the anomalous Hall effect have shown to be an excellent parameter in predicting a material's potential for spintronics applications. Finally, an irradiation study of high quality single crystals of hexaboride materials is proposed in an effort to verify the mechanism of the high-Tc weak ferromagnetism. In this case, the disorder in the system stems from vacancies in the boron sublattice. This experimental research will provide post-doctoral associates, graduate, and undergraduate students with valuable experience and training in the areas of materials synthesis, structural characterization, measurement of physical properties as a function of temperature and magnetic field, and data acquisition and analysis.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
This proposed research will focus on the synthesis of materials that possess very unique physical properties. Semiconductors and magnetic materials, for example, are at the heart of many of today's advanced technologies and devices. This project will investigate how intentionally disordering a material, either chemically, or with defects, can result in enhanced physical properties, such as high temperature magnetism. This proposed research program will aid in the understanding of strongly correlated electron systems in general, and may result in new materials for applications, such as in the emerging field of spintronics (spin-based electronics), which could revolutionize the computer memory industry. Post-doctoral associates, graduate, and undergraduate students will gain valuable experience in the areas of materials synthesis, structural characterization, measurement of physical properties, and data acquisition and analysis. A major component of this research project is in materials synthesis, which provides a natural bridge between teaching and research, especially for undergraduates. They are able to make real contributions in a relatively short amount of time, utilizing a variety of solid state physics and chemistry techniques. Furthermore, the synthesis of new materials is vital to the United States remaining competitive in the race for advanced technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical and structural disorder in condensed matter systems can have a profound effect on their physical properties, such as superconductivity and magnetism.  Likewise, certain materials lack an intrinsic structural symmetry, the so-called noncentrosymmetric materials, which drive unconventional behavior.  We have synthesized high quality single crystals of many of these systems and measured their physical properties as a function of temperature, magnetic field, and pressure.  Here is a partial list of some of the intermetallic materials we have studied:  FeGa3, Fe3Ga4, NiBi3, Co2MnSi, MnNiSi, FeBi2Se4, MnSb2Se4, Ln2Ru3Al15, DyRu2Si2, SmB6, Cr11Ge19, Re6Zr, and BiPd.  While each of these compounds is unique, chemical doping and structural disorder can have an effect on all them, altering their electronic and magnetic properties in ways we can understand with basic physical principles of strongly correlated electron systems.  FeGa3, for example, is a nonmagnetic semiconductor that becomes a ferromagnetic metal when a few percent of the Ga atoms are replaced with Ge.  Through careful control of this doping, the magnetic ordering temperature can be tuned to lower and lower temperatures, eventually reaching absolute zero (a critical point), where exotic and unconventional behavior often appears.  Another example of order from disorder involves the chemical doping of Cr11Ge19.  The Cr atoms are magnetic and order ferromagnetically at 88 K.  If a small percentage of Cr atoms are replaced by Mo atoms, then the ordering temperature unexpectedly rises by a large amount (150 K).  This is counterintuitive to what one would expect, and it demonstrates the underlying complexity in condensed matter systems in which the charge, lattice, orbital, and spin degrees of freedom are highly coupled.

 

This award has contributed to the knowledge base of condensed matter physics in general and to intermetallic strongly correlated electron systems in particular.  Over 25 peer-reviewed journal articles have been published as a direct result of this funding.  This award also supported the Ph.D. research of two graduate students.  The experimental research involved with the grant provided graduate and undergraduate students with valuable experience and training in the areas of materials synthesis, structural characterization, measurement of physical properties as a function of temperature and magnetic field, and data acquisition and analysis. In addition to the synthesis and characterization experience, the undergraduate researchers also learned basic laboratory skills and received training in techniques of low-temperature physics.  Such skills made these students highly competitive as they pursued their graduate degrees in condensed matter physics.  In addition, the broader impacts of this research maintained an educational plan that over a 3-year period enhanced both graduate and undergraduate learning in the laboratory and classroom.  A productive K-12 outreach program was established that targeted pre-college minority students and utilized professors, graduate students, and education majors in physics.  Education in grades K-12 in Louisiana, in particular, suffers from decades of segregation, and conditions for science education in our mainly African-American populated inner-city schools, particularly those in Baton Rouge and New Orleans, are still unsatisfactory. The educational outreach component of this proposal was by no means a cure for all the schools’ science problems, but it provided a concentrated effort that may serve as a catalyst toward furthering the educational future of some young science students.  Getting these students excited about science was an important first step, and one the PI and his research group found to be very personally rewarding!
